lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen and identify key details about vintage markets and write short answers (e.g., prices).
supportStrategies: (Listening) Play short segments of the video. Ask: “How much is the umbrella?” Students write or choose the correct price.
stretchStrategies: Market Voices Role-Play – After watching the video, students create their own 2-line dialogue pretending to be at a vintage market. They must use 1 adjective and 1 question (e.g., “Is it a big umbrella?” “Yes, it is. It’s old too!”). Perform in pairs to the class or teacher. Focus on fluency and expression.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can say how the characters in the video feel and describe how their own lives are similar or different.
supportStrategies: (Social Studies) Ask: “How is this market the same or different from markets in your town?” Use SB visuals for discussion support.
stretchStrategies: Market Voices Role-Play – After watching the video, students create their own 2-line dialogue pretending to be at a vintage market. They must use 1 adjective and 1 question (e.g., “Is it a big umbrella?” “Yes, it is. It’s old too!”). Perform in pairs to the class or teacher. Focus on fluency and expression.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can work together to plan and perform a short role-play.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Role-play) Put students in groups. Give them a market item (flashcard). Each group decides price and practices selling it.

items: Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
